_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY


A. Statement of Purpose

The purpose of this Plan is to identify those incidents, such as fire, explosion, spills or air pollution releases that would effect the surrounding community and guide the response to any such occurrence.  Site personnel are trained properly to deal with specific emergency response situations.  This Plan is written in compliance with the Risk Management Programs under Clean Air Action Section 112(e)(7).  This location is covered by this regulation because Vinyl Acetate Monomer (VAM) is stored and processed at the Resin plant.

This Plan is designed for the employees of The Glidden Company, Emergency Responders and the general public, and contains details of specific response actions and reporting procedures to be followed in the event of an emergency.  This Plan is supported of various procedures contained in the SPCC Plan, Health and Safety Operating Procedures and Work Instructions, Emergency Response Manual, Emergency Response Pre-Plan Manuals, Emergency Action Plan, the Site Process Safety Management Program and various other Resin plant operations manuals.

B. Description of Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

VAM is delivered to the site on railcars which may be up to 30,000 gallons in capacity.  It is stored in two 15,000 gallon tanks prior to being pumped to the Resin plant for processing.  VAM is pumped from the storage tank into a weight tank or reactor vessel inside the plant.  The reaction converts all the monomer into a non-hazardous polymer (latex).

C. Worst Case Scenarios

Onsite locations (?processes?) involving VAM include:

1. An outside rail siding for 30,000-gallon tank car shipments, approximately 600 feet from the nearest offsite building, and 300 feet from the nearest (west) fence line.

2. Two outside 15,000-galon storage tanks in a diked area just north of the rail siding, approximately 330 feet from the nearest (west) fence line.

3.  6,000-gallon reactor inside a process building.

4.

2,000-gallon weigh tank inside a process building.

5.  20-foot high, 4-inch transfer pipeline, almost 400 feet from the nearest offsite building, and 300 feet from the nearest fence line.

A worse case release is defined as instantaneous loss of the largest full vessel in each affected process on site.  Review of the Site, it is clear that the RMP Worst Case Scenario is the loss of a full railcar, which would instantaneously release 30,000 gallons (234,360 pounds) of VAM.  A railcar is the largest single vessel, there are not administrative controls in place that would prohibit a full car, and the cars are typically spotted at least as close to the nearest fence line as any other vessel.  

D. Accident Release Prevention Program

The facility achieves compliance with the accidental release prevention requirement through our OSHA PSM process.  Critical components of the process are as follows:
 

PART 1910.119(c) -- EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION

The facility has had a Process Safety Management Employee Participation Policy in place since April 1993.  The policy discusses employee participation in such areas as:  hazard analysis, operating procedures, training, mechanical integrity, management of change, incident/accident investigation, emergency planning and response, and safety and health committees.

PART 1910.119(d) ? PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION

Process Safety Information pertaining to chemical, health and physical hazards of highly hazardous chemicals is met through the use of MSDSs.  Information pertaining to the technology of the process can be found in the reactor procedures and batch slips for the Resin Plant.  Additionally, to meet this requirement the facility conducts Hazard and Operability Studies (HAZOPS) to determine the consequence of deviations, including safety and health concerns and systems in-place to prevent deviations.  Information pertaining to the equipment in the process is maintained by the Plant Engineer.  P&IDs exist for all regulated processes

in the Resin  plant.  Additionally, there are individual dossiers on all pieces of critical equipment which include information on:  materials of construction, electrical classification, relief systems, ventilation, design codes and standards, and safety systems.  Maintenance of critical pieces of equipment is monitored through the MP2 System.

PART 1910.119(e) ? PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS

The facility has conducted an initial process hazard analysis of the Resin Plant in 1993, revalidations in 1999 and 2001.  The facility uses HAZOP methodologies in conducting the hazard analysis.  This hazard analysis is conducted by a team of employees with expertise in engineering and process operations and the team leader has had formal hazard analysis training.  As a result of the study, a list of recommendations are developed.  The recommendations are sent to the appropriate Production Manager and are followed up on by the SHE Manager.  Documentation of the hazard analysis and recommendations are kept on file in the SHE Department.

PART 1910.119(f) ? OPERATING PROCEDURES

The Resin Plant has a complete set of operating procedures for processes regulated under the standard.  The operating procedures contain sections on steps for each operating phase, operating limits, safety and health considerations, and safety systems.  In the Resin Plant these procedures are kept electronically, hard copies are located in the Control Room for Operators and in the lunchroom for Assistant Operators and Material Handlers.  In addition to the operating procedure the facility maintains a set of Safety and Health Procedures and Work Instructions that address such issues as: Lockout/Tagout, Confined Space Entry, Safe Work, Hot Work Line Breaking, Security, Contractor Safety, Emergency Action Plan, etc. Operating Procedures are reviewed annually.

PART 1910.119(g) ? TRAINING

All employees who work in areas covered by the standard have been provided with initial and refresher training.  This traini

ng is done under an Operator Certification Program which was set up to comply wit the Process Safety Management Regulations.  Documentation of the training is kept on file by the Production Manager.  Employees are trained at least every 3 years on work specific procedures.

PART 1910.119(h) ? CONTRACTORS

The facility has a Contractor Safety Procedure in place.  This procedure addresses safety requirements for Contractors working on Site and includes a pre-qualification safety requirement and periodic auditing.  In addition, the facility keeps records on contractor hours worked as well as any incidents and injuries.

PART 1910.119(i) ? PRE-STARTUP SAFETY REVIEW

The Site performs Pre-Startup Saftey Reviews on all new processes and modified processes.  Modifications to existing operations are covered under the Management of Change process.  The facility has a Management of Change policy (#277) in place and in use.

PART 1910.119(j) ? MECHANICAL INTEGRITY

The facility conducts an inspection and preventive maintenance program of all critical equipment.  The MP2 System is used to track equipment and what work has been done to date.  Procedures for maintaining critical equipment can be found in the Paints Engineering Practices (PEPs) and General Engineering Practices (GEPs) which are located in the Site Engineer?s office.  Training for Maintenance employees is provided on the job under the guidance of an experienced employee with specialized third party training given as needed.

PART 1910.199(k) ? HOT WORK PERMIT

The facility has a Hot Work procedure (#109) in place.  Forms, monitoring equipment and training has been provided to Shift Supervisors, who are responsibility for issuing the permits.

PART 1910.119(l) ? MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE

The facility has a Management of Change procedure (#277) in place and in use.

PART 1910.119(m) ? INCIDENT INVESTIGATION

Incident investigation and reporting is covered in procedure (#716).  The facility investigates all accidents, not

just those in covered processes.  Recommendations from the investigation are forwarded to the appropriate parties for implementation.

PART 1910.119(n) ? EMERGENCY PLANNING AND RESPONSE

The facility has an Emergency Response Manual in place.  The Manual is located in the SHE Department and in the office of each Production Manager.  The facility also has an Emergency Response Team to respond to on site hazardous material emergencies.

PART 1910.119(o) ? COMPLIANCE AUDITS

The facility conducts compliance audits of the Process Safety management program every three years.  Audits were conducted in 1999 and 2002.  Action plans were developed to address any deficiencies noted during the audit.

PART 1910.119(p) ? TRADE SECRETS

Not applicable.

E. Organizational Responsibilities

The Huron plant of The Glidden Company is keeping with Company policy will maintain an Emergency Response Team at this location.

The Team will be under the direction and training of the SHE Manager.  Production Manager and supervisors will serve as on-scene coordinators.

Hands-on field training will be conducted at least annually utilizing all equipment expected to be used by the team.  Additional classroom / preplanning activities will be conducted at least one time during the year.

Drills with the Huron Fire Department and/or the Erie County Emergency Management Agency are conducted periodically.

The Emergency Response Team functions will include fighting incipient fires, confined space rescue, protecting exposures from fires onsite or in adjacent plants, securing leaks and spills, providing support activities to the public Fire Department and other outside agencies and providing tactical guidance to the public Fire Department.  The command structure for the Emergency Response Team is as follows:

Operations Director
The Operations Director is assigned overall responsibility to protect personnel, site facility, and the public.  The Operations Director will be available at the main contro

l center for counsel and overall guidance during an emergency.  

Incident Commander (IC):  The IC organizes and directs the emergency control activities.  The IC?s responsibilities include establishing control centers and managing all operations of the emergency response action.  The IC will establish headquarters as close to the emergency scene as safety permits.

Emergency Response Team Leader:  The Team Leader, along with the Emergency Response Team, is responsible for correcting the emergency situation as promptly as possible; this may include shutting down and securing operations.  The Team Leader also provides guidance to the Emergency Response Team.  The Team Leader communicates directly with the Incident Commander.

The facility Emergency Response Team Leader is also the Coordinator for the Erie County Emergency Response Team.  The Environmental Coordinator is a Committee member of the LEPC (Erie County Emergency Management Agency).

All fire and sprinkler (water flow), temperature, security and high level alarms on the Hazardous Waste tanks are monitored continuously by a third party security company.  The Sheriff and Fire Departments are notified by the security company.
